child.pub-comments: Bender wishes to emphasize the difference between the Omotik language listed here and the Afro-asiatic Omotic family, the similar naming of which he asserts is purely coincidental (Bender: 2000 48).
child.publications: Bender, M. Lionel. 2000. Nilo-Saharan. In Bernd Heine & Derek Nurse (eds.), African Languages: An Introduction, 1 edn., 43-73. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0521661781

child.pub-comments: Node not named by author. These languages were separated from other groups by semicolons. It is unclear what Bender's intentions were, but this has been interpreted in this tree to be a subgroup.
child.publications: Bender, M. Lionel. 2000. Nilo-Saharan. In Bernd Heine & Derek Nurse (eds.), African Languages: An Introduction, 1 edn., 43-73. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0521661781

child.pub-comments: Bender prefers the neutral characterization (a), (b), (c), over the geographic due to overlapping geographic locations (Bender 2000:46).

child.pub-comments: "The name 'Songay' is often seen as 'Songhai', using French spelling. It is actually 'soŋay', with the velar nasal for which neither French nor English has a single letter, and one should be wary of confusing it with Somrai, a small Chadic language of Chad" (Bender 2000: 47). 3,227,000 speakers.
child.publications: Bender, M. Lionel. 2000. Nilo-Saharan. In Bernd Heine & Derek Nurse (eds.), African Languages: An Introduction, 1 edn., 43-73. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0521661781

child.geography: East of Lake Chad to northwest Sudan

root.pub-comments: Bender wishes to "emphasize the preliminary nature of this work, but [he does] think it is a start in the right direction" (Bender 2000: 54).
